title: Options for Employee Profit Sharing and Equity
cardShortDescription: Profit sharing is a way to provide employees with a direct financial stake in the company’s success. It can be used as a tool to motivate employees to work harder and more efficiently. It can also be used as a way to attract and retain top talent. Profit sharing can be a win-win for both the employer and the employee.
content:
Options for Employee Profit Sharing and Equity

1. Profit Sharing Without Equity

The first option is to recognize that there are potentially negative tax implications if you give your employee equity and to not grant them any equity at all. You could instead have an employment agreement to provide the employee with a percentage of the net profits from your business as a bonus. The employee would still get the benefit of getting a percentage of the net profits without having to go out of pocket to purchase their equity or potentially having to recognize as taxable income the fair market value of the equity.

A drawback to this approach is psychologically people are often motivated more when they own equity in a company than with a profit-sharing plan, even if the net take-home is the same. There is something innately appealing to owning a piece of the company that you work for.

2. Grant Equity

If you grant your employee equity, the employee might have to recognize as taxable income the fair market value of that equity just as if you had given the employee a car, a house, or anything else of value. One example of this concept is if you were to get a World Series ring for working for a Major League Baseball team, you would have to pay taxes on the fair market value of that ring. The same could apply to the equity that you give to your employees.

You could pay your employee a bonus to cover that tax liability, but the bonus would be taxed. For example, if you grant your employee $100,000 worth of equity and you wanted to cover that employee’s tax bill for getting the equity, you might have to bonus the employee $100,000, so after the employee pays taxes, the net amount is enough to cover the taxes they owe for being given their equity.

A drawback to this approach is that there could be two layers of taxation: (i) first when you pay the bonus, and (ii) again when the employee pays taxes on the fair market value of their equity. Uncle Sam loves this approach. Our clients? Not so much.

3. Sell the Equity to Your Employee for Its Fair Market Value

A third option is to sell the equity to your employee for its fair market value. The advantage of this approach is that the employee might not have an immediate taxable event.

A drawback is that the equity would be less of an incentive, as the employee would have to write a check to your company. “Thank you for the equity that I paid for?”

How to Create a Profit Sharing Plan

Profit sharing is a way to provide employees with a direct financial stake in the company’s success. It can be used as a tool to motivate employees to work harder and more efficiently. It can also be used as a way to attract and retain top talent. Profit sharing can be a win-win for both the employer and the employee.

1. Determine the Purpose of the Plan

Before you create a profit-sharing plan, you need to determine the purpose of the plan. What are you trying to accomplish with the plan? Are you trying to motivate employees to work harder? Are you trying to attract and retain top talent? Are you trying to reward employees for their hard work and dedication? Once you determine the purpose of the plan, you can move on to the next step.

2. Determine the Structure of the Plan

Once you determine the purpose of the plan, you need to determine the structure of the plan. How will the plan be structured? Will it be a cash-based plan or an equity-based plan? Will it be a discretionary plan or a formula-based plan? Will it be a one-time plan or an ongoing plan? Once you determine the structure of the plan, you can move on to the next step.

3. Determine the Eligibility Requirements

Once you determine the structure of the plan, you need to determine the eligibility requirements. Who will be eligible to participate in the plan? Will all employees be eligible? Will only certain employees be eligible? Once you determine the eligibility requirements, you can move on to the next step.

4. Determine the Allocation Formula

Once you determine the eligibility requirements, you need to determine the allocation formula. How will the profits be allocated to the employees? Will it be based on salary? Will it be based on performance? Will it be based on tenure? Once you determine the allocation formula, you can move on to the next step.

5. Communicate the Plan to Employees

Once you determine the allocation formula, you need to communicate the plan to employees. You need to explain the purpose of the plan, the structure of the plan, the eligibility requirements, and the allocation formula. You need to make sure that employees understand how the plan works and what they need to do to participate in the plan. Once you communicate the plan to employees, you can move on to the next step.

6. Monitor and Evaluate the Plan

Once you communicate the plan to employees, you need to monitor and evaluate the plan. You need to make sure that the plan is achieving its intended purpose. You need to make sure that the plan is motivating employees to work harder and more efficiently. You need to make sure that the plan is attracting and retaining top talent. You need to make sure that the plan is rewarding employees for their hard work and dedication. Once you monitor and evaluate the plan, you can move on to the next step.

7. Make Adjustments as Needed

Once you monitor and evaluate the plan, you need to make adjustments as needed. You need to make sure that the plan is achieving its intended purpose. You need to make sure that the plan is motivating employees to work harder and more efficiently. You need to make sure that the plan is attracting and retaining top talent. You need to make sure that the plan is rewarding employees for their hard work and dedication. Once you make adjustments as needed, you can move on to the next step.
